terrapeer.vui.j3dui.control.inputs
Class Input

java.lang.Object
  terrapeer.vui.j3dui.control.inputs.Input
public abstract class Input
extends java.lang.Object

Provides AWT and input sensor specific event constants and utilities.

Notes:
Here, mouse buttons are defined in their order of precedence. The "first" button is typically the left one. The "second" button the right one. And, the "third" button the middle one. Because of cross-platform concerns and because there seems to not be a reliable way to simulate a third mouse button on Windows, the first and third button together is a built-in alias for the third button.

In the AWT a one-button mouse is assumed, with the other buttons corresponding to modifier keys. Specifically, the "second" button corresponds to the "meta" key and the "third" button corresponds to the "alt" key. At least in Windows, however, the third (middle) button causes both the "ctrl" and "alt" key modifiers to be true. Because of this, the "ctrl" and "alt" modifiers should not be used with the third button.

Because of the overloading of keys for mouse buttons, certain modifiers are not included (i.e. Meta) but certain modifier combinations are included (i.e. Shift+Ctrl, Shift+Alt) and others are excluded (e.g. Ctrl+Alt).

Although the escape key is technically not a modifier key (i.e. it can not be used in conjunction with other keys) it is included with the modifier key constants and sensor for simplicity.

All "raw" mouse positions are "cooked" as soon as possible in a sensor. Cooked mouse position is in a right-handed coordinate system with Y increasing "up". For speed, display coordinates are relative to the display canvas upper left corner (i.e. Y position in the canvas is negative).

Input

Method Detail

cookMouse

public static javax.vecmath.Tuple2d cookMouse(int rawX,
                                              int rawY,
                                              javax.vecmath.Tuple2d copy)
Cooks the raw mouse position (actually any screen-based position) so that it conforms to a right-hand coordinate system (Y increasing up) and is output as a floating point vector. The origin remains at the upper left corner of the display space.

Parameters:
rawX - Raw mouse X position (increasing right).
rawY - Raw mouse Y position (increasing down).
copy - Container for the copied return value.
Returns:
Cooked mouse position (right-handed).

uncookMouseX

public static int uncookMouseX(javax.vecmath.Tuple2d cooked)
Uncooks the cooked mouse X position so that it conforms to the Java screen coordinate system (Y increasing down). The origin remains at the upper left corner of the display space.

Parameters:
cooked - Cooked mouse position (right-handed).
Returns:
Raw mouse X position (increasing right).

uncookMouseY

public static int uncookMouseY(javax.vecmath.Tuple2d cooked)
Uncooks the cooked mouse Y position so that it conforms to the Java screen coordinate system (Y increasing down). The origin remains at the upper left corner of the display space.

Returns:
Raw mouse Y position (increasing down).

whichButton

public static int whichButton(java.awt.event.InputEvent event)
Returns the current button choice from the AWT event. See whichButton(int) for details.

Parameters:
event - Input event.
Returns:
Mouse button choice (BUTTON_???).

whichButton

public static int whichButton(int awtFlags)
Returns the current button choice corresponding to the AWT event flags. In the case of multiple buttons being pressed, the order of precedence is: First, Second, Third, with the exception that the first and second button together is an alias for the third button and has the highest precedence.

Parameters:
awtFlags - Bit flags such as those obtained from InputEvent.getModifiers().
Returns:
Mouse button choice (BUTTON_???).

toButtonString

public static java.lang.String toButtonString(int flags)
Coverts the button state flags into a string.

Parameters:
flags - Input button state flags (BUTTON_???).
Returns:
String equivalent of state flags.

whichClick

Returns the current click choice from the AWT event.

Parameters:
event - Input event.
Returns:
Mouse click choice (CLICK_???).

toClickString

Coverts the click state flags into a string.

Parameters:
flags - Input click state flags (CLICK_???).
Returns:
String equivalent of state flags.

whichModifier

public static int whichModifier(java.awt.event.KeyEvent event)
Returns the current modifier key choice from the AWT key event, including the escape key, which is exclusive of all other modifiers.

Parameters:
event - Key event.
Returns:
Modifier choice (MODIFIER_???).

whichModifier

public static int whichModifier(java.awt.event.InputEvent event)
Returns the current modifier key choice from the AWT event. See whichModifier(int) for details.

Parameters:
event - Input event.
Returns:
Modifier choice (MODIFIER_???).

whichModifier

public static int whichModifier(int awtFlags)
Returns the current modifier key choice corresponding to the AWT event flags (does not include the escape key). Note the order of precedence, which starts with Ctrl+Alt. Note also that, to avoid conflicts with the third mouse button in Windows (i.e. Ctrl+Alt), Ctrl+Alt returns MODIFIER_NONE and Shift+Ctrl+Alt returns MODIFIER_SHIFT.

Parameters:
awtFlags - Bit flags such as those obtained from InputEvent.getModifiers().
Returns:
Modifier choice (MODIFIER_???).

toModifierString

public static java.lang.String toModifierString(int flags)
Coverts the modifier state flags into a string.

Parameters:
flags - Input modifier state flags (MODIFIER_???).
Returns:
String equivalent of state flags.

whichKey

public static int whichKey(java.awt.event.KeyEvent event)
Returns the current key involved in the AWT event. If a key is being released then the key choice is interpreted as KEY_NONE.

Parameters:
event - Input event.
Returns:
Key code (KEY_NONE or VK_???).

whichArrow

public static int whichArrow(java.awt.event.KeyEvent event)
Returns the current arrow key from the AWT event.

Parameters:
event - Input event.
Returns:
Arrow choice (ARROW_???).

public static java.lang.String toArrowString(int flags)
Coverts the arrow state flags into a string.

flags - Input click state flags (ARROW_???).
Returns:
String equivalent of state flags.
